column1: Long Island City (LIC) is a residential and commercial neighborhood on the extreme western tip of Queens
column2: New York City
column3: on the western edge of Long Island.  It is bordered by Astoria to the north; the East River to the west; Hazen Street
column4: 49th Street
column5: and New Calvary Cemetery in Sunnyside to the east; and Newtown Creek—which separates Queens from Greenpoint
column6: Brooklyn—to the south.

column2: Long Island City was originally the seat of government of the Town of Newtown
column3: before becoming part of the City of Greater New York in 1898.  In the early 21st century
column4: Long Island City became known for its rapid and ongoing residential growth and gentrification
column5: its waterfront parks
column6: and its thriving arts community. The area has a high concentration of art galleries
column7: art institutions
column8: and studio space.Long Island City is the eastern terminus of the Queensboro Bridge
column9: the only non-tolled automotive route connecting Queens and Manhattan. Northwest of the bridge are the Queensbridge Houses
column10: a development of the New York City Housing Authority and the largest public housing complex in the Western Hemisphere.

column1: Long Island City is part of Queens Community District 1 to the north and Queens Community District 2 to the south. It is patrolled by the New York City Police Department's 108th Precinct. Politically
column2: Long Island City is represented by the New York City Council's 26th District.
a city of its own
column3: was created on May 4
column4: 1870 from the merger of the Village of Astoria and the hamlets of Ravenswood
column5: Hunters Point
column6: Blissville
column7: Sunnyside
column10: Bowery Bay and Middleton in the Town of Newtown. At the time of its incorporation
column13: 000 residents. Its charter provided for an elected mayor and a ten-member Board of Alderman with two representing each of the city's five wards. City ordinances could be passed by a majority vote of the Board of Aldermen and the mayor's signature.Long Island City held its first election on July 5
column14: 1870. Residents elected A.D. Delmars the first mayor; Delmars ran as both a Democrat and a Republican. The first elected Board of Aldermen was H. Rudolph and Patrick Lonirgan (Ward 1); Francis McNena and William E. Bragaw (Ward 2); George Hunter and Mr. Williams (Third Ward); James R. Bennett and John Wegart (Ward Four); and E.M. Hartshort and William Carlin (Fifth Ward). The mayor and the aldermen were inaugurated on July 18
column16: Mayor De Bevoise nearly bankrupted the Long Island City government by embezzlement
column17: of which he was convicted. Many dissatisfied residents of Astoria circulated a petition to ask the New York State Legislature to allow it to secede from Long Island City and reincorporate as the Village of Astoria
column18: as it existed prior to the incorporation of Long Island City
column19: in 1884. The petition was ultimately dropped by the citizens.Long Island City continued to exist as an incorporated city until 1898
column20: when Queens was annexed to New York City. The last mayor of Long Island City was an Irish-American named Patrick Jerome "Battle-Axe" Gleason.

column1: The Common Council of Long Island City in 1873 adopted the coat of arms as "emblematical of the varied interest represented by Long Island City." It was designed by George H. Williams
column2: of Ravenswood. The overall composition was inspired by New York City's coat of arms. The shield is rich in historic allusion
column3: including Native American
column4: Dutch
column5: and English symbols. In 1898
column6: Long Island City became part of New York City.

column1: === After incorporation into New York City ===
The city surrendered its independence in 1898 to become part of the City of Greater New York. However
column2: Long Island City survives as ZIP Code 11101 and ZIP Code prefix 111 (with its own main post office) and was formerly a sectional center facility (SCF). The Greater Astoria Historical Society
column3: a nonprofit cultural and historical organization documenting the Long Island City area's history
column4: has operated since 1985.

column2: three subway tunnels
column3: the Queens-Midtown Tunnel
column4: and the Queensboro Bridge were built to connect the neighborhood to Manhattan. By the 1970s
column5: the factories in Long Island City were being abandoned. In 1981
column6: Queens West on the west side of Long Island City was developed to revitalize the area.

column2: the neighborhood was rezoned from an industrial neighborhood to a residential neighborhood
column3: and the area underwent gentrification
column4: with developments such as Hunter's Point South being built in the area. Since then
column5: there has been substantial commercial and residential growth in Long Island City
column6: with 41 new residential apartment buildings being built just between 2010 and 2017.  A resident of nearby Woodside proposed establishing a Japantown in Long Island City in 2006
column7: though this did not occur. By the mid-2010s
column8: Long Island City was one of New York City's fastest-growing neighborhoods

column1: Long Island City was once home to many factories and bakeries
column2: some of which are finding new uses. The former Silvercup bakery is now home to Silvercup Studios
column3: which has produced notable works such as NBC's 30 Rock and HBO's Sex and the City. The Silvercup sign is visible from the IRT Flushing Line and BMT Astoria Line trains going into and out of Queensboro Plaza (7
column5: N
column6: and ​W trains). The former Sunshine Bakery is now one of the buildings which houses LaGuardia Community College. Other buildings on the campus originally served as the location of the Ford Instrument Company
column7: which was at one time a major producer of precision machines and devices.  Artist Isamu Noguchi converted a photo-engraving plant into a workshop; the site is now the Noguchi Museum
column8: a space dedicated to his work.

column2: a manufacturing site producing items like distributor caps
column3: was once located in the industrial neighborhood of Long Island City until purchased by Acuman Partners in 2008 for $40 million. The Standard Motor Products Building was put on the market by Acuman in 2014 and acquired by RXR Realty
column4: LLC for $110 million. The former factory built in 1919 now houses the Jim Henson Company
column5: Society Awards
column6: and a commercial rooftop farm run by Brooklyn Grange.High-rise housing is being built on a former Pepsi-Cola site on the East River. From June 2002 to September 2004
column7: the former Swingline Staplers plant was the temporary headquarters of the Museum of Modern Art. Other former factories in Long Island City include Fisher Electronics and Chiclets Gum. Long Island City's turn-of-the-century district of residential towers
column9: is located along the East River
column10: just north of the LIRR's Long Island City Station. Redevelopment in Queens West reflects the intent to have the area as a major residential area in New York City
column11: with its high-rise residences very close to public transportation
column12: making it convenient for commuters to travel to Manhattan by ferry or subway. The first tower
column14: opened in 1998 with an elementary school at the base. Others have been completed since then and more are being planned or under construction.

column2: named for its navigable tributary of Newtown Creek
column3: that occupied what today is Queens Plaza. Dutch Kills was an important road hub during the American Revolutionary War
column4: and the site of a British Army garrison from 1776 to 1783. The area supported farms during the 19th century. The tributary of the same name connected to Sunswick Creek at its north end
column5: which facilitated commerce in the region. The canalization of Newtown Creek and the Kills at the end of the 19th century intensified industrial development of the area
column6: which prospered until the middle of the 20th century.  The neighborhood is currently undergoing a massive rezoning of mixed residential and commercial properties.

column1: Hunters Point is on the south side of Long Island City. It contains the Hunters Point Historic District
column2: a national historic district that includes 19 contributing buildings along 45th Avenue between 21st and 23rd Streets. They are a set of townhouses built in the late 19th century. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973.Queens West and Hunter's Point South are located on the waterfront.

column1: Long Island City is home to a large and dynamic artistic community.

column1: The Fisher Landau Center for Art is a private foundation that offers regular exhibitions of contemporary art that closed to the public in November 2017.
Across the street from Socrates Sculpture Park is the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Museum
column2: founded in 1985 by Japanese-American sculptor Isamu Noguchi. After undergoing a two-and-a-half-year renovation completed at a cost of $13.5 million
column3: the museum reopened in 2004 with newer and advanced facilities.

column2: an affiliate of the Museum of Modern Art
column3: is the oldest and second-largest non-profit arts center in the United States solely devoted to contemporary art. It is named after the former public school in which it is housed.

column1: SculptureCenter is New York City's only non-profit exhibition space dedicated to contemporary and innovative sculpture. SculptureCenter re-located from Manhattan's Upper East Side to a former trolley repair shop in Long Island City
column2: Queens renovated by artist/designer Maya Lin in 2002. Founded by artists in 1928
column3: SculptureCenter has undergone much evolution and growth
column4: and continues to expand and challenge the definition of sculpture. SculptureCenter commissions new work and presents exhibits by emerging and established
column5: national and international artists. The museum also hosts a diverse range of public programs including lectures
column6: dialogues
column7: and performances.

column1: Socrates Sculpture Park is an outdoor sculpture park located one block from the Noguchi Museum at the intersection of Broadway and Vernon Boulevard.
See.me is web-based arts organization located in Long Island City. The organization is dedicated to supporting artistic talent

column13: 000 live births. Long Island City has a high population of residents who are uninsured. In 2018
column14: this population of uninsured residents was estimated to be 12% in Community Board 1 and 16% in Community Board 2
column15: compared to the citywide rate of 12%.The concentration of fine particulate matter
column16: the deadliest type of air pollutant
column17: is 0.0078 milligrams per cubic metre (7.8×10−9 oz/cu ft) in northern Long Island City and 0.0093 milligrams per cubic metre (9.3×10−9 oz/cu ft) in southern Long Island City. Nineteen percent of Community Board 1 residents and fourteen percent of Community Board 2 residents are smokers
column18: compared to the city average of 14% of residents being smokers. In Community Board 1
column21: and 29% have high blood pressure—compared to the citywide averages of 24%
column26: and 23% have high blood pressure. In addition
column27: 22% of children in northern Long Island City and 19% of children in southern Long Island City are obese
column28: compared to the citywide average of 20%.Eighty-nine percent of Community Board 1 residents and ninety-two percent of Community Board 2 residents eat some fruits and vegetables every day
column29: which is higher than the city's average of 87%. In 2018
column30: 79% of residents in both areas described their health as "good"
column33: slightly higher than the city's average of 78%. For every supermarket
column34: there are 17 bodegas in southern Long Island City and 10 in northern Long Island City.The nearest large hospitals in the area are the Elmhurst Hospital Center in Elmhurst and the Mount Sinai Hospital of Queens in Astoria.

column1: Long Island City is covered by ZIP Code 11101. The United States Post Office operates the Long Island City Station at 46-02 21st Street.
Long Island City generally has a slightly higher ratio of college-educated residents than the rest of the city as of 2018. In Community Board 1
column2: half of residents (50%) have a college education or higher
column3: while 16% have less than a high school education and 33% are high school graduates or have some college education. In Community Board 2
column4: 45% of residents age 25 and older have a college education or higher
column5: 19% have less than a high school education and 35% are high school graduates or have some college education. By contrast
column6: 39% of Queens residents and 43% of city residents have a college education or higher. The percentage of Community Board 1 students excelling in math rose from 43 percent in 2000 to 65 percent in 2011
column7: and reading achievement rose from 47% to 49% during the same time period. Similarly
column8: the percentage of Community Board 2 students excelling in math rose from 40% in to 65%
column9: and reading achievement rose from 45% to 49%
column10: during the same time period.Long Island City's rate of elementary school student absenteeism is about equal to the rest of New York City. Nineteen percent of elementary school students in Community Board 1 and eleven percent in Community Board 2 missed twenty or more days per school year
column11: less than the citywide average of 20%. Additionally
column12: 78% of high school students in Community Board 1 and 86% of high school students in Community Board 2 graduate on time
column13: more than the citywide average of 75%.The New York City Department of Education operates a facility in Long Island City housing the Office of School Support Services and several related departments.

column2: which will bring LIRR trains to Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan
column3: is under construction and is scheduled to open in 2022; this project will create a new train tunnel beneath the East River
column4: connecting Long Island City and Queens with the East Side of Manhattan.During the summer
column5: the New York Water Taxi Company used to operate Water Taxi Beach
column6: a public beach artificially created on a wharf along the East River
column7: accessible at the corner of Second Street and Borden Avenue. It was discontinued in 2011 due to new construction on the site of the old landing.In June 2011
column8: NY Waterway started service to points along the East River. On May 1
column10: that route became part of the NYC Ferry's East River route
column11: which runs between Pier 11/Wall Street in Manhattan's Financial District and the East 34th Street Ferry Landing in Murray Hill
column13: with five intermediate stops in Brooklyn and Queens. One NYC Ferry stop for the East River route is located at Hunters Point South
column14: while another NYC Ferry stop for a route to Astoria is located at Gantry Plaza State Park.There are plans to build the Brooklyn–Queens Connector (BQX)
column15: a light rail system that would run along the waterfront from Red Hook in Brooklyn through Long Island City to Astoria. However
column16: the system is projected to cost $2.7 billion
column17: and the projected opening has been delayed until at least 2029.
